word.entryDescription: made from animal skin, often cow
word.entryExample: The boy in the photo is wearing a black leather jacket.

word.entryDescription: to go away from
word.entryExample: Bottlenose dolphins grow up and leave their mothers when they are three to five years old.

word.entryDescription: an educational talk given to a group of people, usually students
word.entryExample: Her lectures used to start at 9:30.

word.entryDescription: west if you are facing north
word.entryExample: Turn left at the hotel and go over the bridge.

word.entryDescription: uneaten food after a meal
word.entryExample: The leftovers from Sunday's roast dinner would be recycled over the next few days.

word.entryDescription: the two long parts of the lower half of your body
word.entryExample: You walk with your legs.

word.entryDescription: the lasting memory of something
word.entryExample: The Beatles' legacy is enduring and people all over the world still listen to their music.

word.entryDescription: allowed by law, or relating to the law
word.entryExample: Are there any reasons for making graffiti legal?

word.entryDescription: close-fitting trousers worn by women, made of cloth that stretches easily
word.entryExample: I sometimes wear leggings with a dress, instead of tights.

word.entryDescription: to make laws about something
word.entryExample: The power to legislate and to tax lies at the federal level.

word.entryDescription: a very sour fruit with a thick yellow skin and yellow flesh
word.entryExample: Lemons are good for your health.

word.entryDescription: a sweet fizzy drink with the taste of lemon
word.entryExample: Would you like a glass of cold lemonade?

word.entryDescription: a piece of curved glass or plastic through which light passes and bends, and which is used in glasses, cameras, microscopes, etc in order to view things clearly or produce images
word.entryExample: If you want to change lenses to take pictures of things far away, you should not buy a Compact Camera.

word.entryDescription: a red, green or brown seed which is dried and used as food
word.entryExample: At the barbecue there were lentil burgers for the vegetarians.

word.entryDescription: a smaller amount or degree
word.entryExample: There are 15 in a rugby team, but there are two less in a football team.

word.entryDescription: a period of time in which you are taught something
word.entryExample: The English lesson was good.

word.entryDescription: to make somebody disappointed in you by not doing something you agreed to, by not behaving as you should, etc
word.entryExample: Thank you for your faith in me – I won't let you down!

word.entryDescription: to behave in a way that embarrasses or disappoints your family, friends etc
word.entryExample: Mary is a reliable person - she'd never let the side down.

word.entryDescription: a message which you write on a piece of paper, put in an envelope and send
word.entryExample: I don't write letters any more, I only write emails.

word.entryDescription: a small hole in a door or wall for the postman to put letter into
word.entryExample: He pushed the magazine through the letterbox.

word.entryDescription: a vegetable with large green leaves often eaten raw in salads
word.entryExample: We need a lot of lettuce for the salad.

word.entryDescription: a standard of ability
word.entryExample: I'm studying advanced level French, intermediate Spanish and elementary Chinese, which is for beginners.

word.entryDescription: calm and able to make sensible decisions even in difficult situations
word.entryExample: I was happy to make her captain of the hockey team where she is a good natured coach to the younger girls and is always level-headed under pressure.

word.entryDescription: a room containing a lot of books, magazines, etc, which people can borrow or read there
word.entryExample: There are a lot of English books in the library.

word.entryDescription: to put your body into a flat position on a surface
word.entryExample: Then he went to his room to lie down.

word.entry: life and soul of the party
word.entryDescription: a kind of person who enjoys social occasions and makes them more enjoyable for others
word.entryExample: Paul was having a very enjoyable time and was clearly the life and soul of the party.

word.entryDescription: that is going to save somebody’s life, or is suited to save life
word.entryExample: You must have a life-saving qualification and a qualification in First Aid is desirable.

word.entryDescription: that could cause someone to die
word.entryExample: I thought I would be saving lives and helping people who have life-threatening injuries.

word.entryDescription: someone who works at a beach or a swimming pool and whose job is to to rescue people who are in danger in the water
word.entryExample: You must listen to the lifeguards on the swimming pool.

word.entryDescription: the way you live according to the things you do, the things you own, etc
word.entryExample: Tennis is considered to be just a part of a healthy lifestyle by many young players.

word.entryDescription: a small room that carries people up and down inside a building
word.entryExample: I took the lift to the tenth floor.

word.entryDescription: (of a rocket) to leave the ground
word.entryExample: Look, the rocket is lifting off!

word.entryDescription: when a rocket leaves the ground
word.entryExample: He was really excited when he saw the lift-off on TV.

word.entryDescription: (past simple and past participle form 'lit') to start to burn; to make something start to burn
word.entryExample: I hope this flame lights soon.

word.entryDescription: a bright flash of electricity in the sky
word.entryExample: This tree is damaged because it was struck by lightning.

word.entryDescription: to think that something is good or nice
word.entryExample: I really like your dress, Kim.

word.entryDescription: to like something the most
word.entryExample: Which chocolate do you like best - milk, dark or white?

word.entryDescription: difficulties with movement
word.entryExample: Patients with limited mobility find animal therapy helpful.

word.entryDescription: a long thin mark
word.entryExample: Right, well stand in line, please.

word.entryDescription: to form a line
word.entryExample: Line up outside, please.

word.entryDescription: an animal like a very large cat that lives in Africa
word.entryExample: Many people say that lion is the king of all animals.

word.entryDescription: to pay attention to what somebody is saying, a sound, a piece of music, etc
word.entryExample: We listen to a story in the afternoon.

word.entryDescription: to pay attention to what somebody is saying, a sound, a piece of music, etc
word.entryExample: I like listening to audiobooks on the bus.

word.entryDescription: a unit for measuring the amount of liquid; 1000 millilitres
word.entryExample: Is there any milk? Not really, only half a litre.

word.entryDescription: waste paper, plastic, cans, bottles left lying in a public place
word.entryExample: Pick that up! You can't just throw litter on the ground!

word.entryDescription: not much or enough
word.entryExample: There's little to do in this village.

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'live' – to stay in a place
word.entryExample: The parrot lived on the island.

word.entryDescription: full of energy, activity and excitement
word.entryExample: Cities are lively, varied, cosmopolitan places with plenty of culture and entertainment.

word.entryDescription: a room where people sit and relax
word.entryExample: We watch television in the living room.

word.entryDescription: a reptile with legs, a long body and a long tail
word.entryExample: It's not a baby crocodile, it's a lizard.
